questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with swelling and tenderness of his left maxilla, and left subconjunctival haemorrhage after falling on his head in the playground at school. There was no loss of consciousness during or after the incident. He is alert & conscious and his vital signs are stable including GCS 15/15 at the time of presentation and one hour later. He is exquisitely tender in palpation of his left maxillary bone. Which is the most appropriate initial investigation?
questions.solution:
• There is absolutely no indication in the stem indicating of neurological deficit to order CT scan or MRI. Moreover, there are no signs of intracranial haemorrhage.
  • Swelling and tenderness over left maxilla could represent a maxillary fracture.

questions.text: A 14-year old boy develops severe breathlessness during a game of football. On examination, there is absent breath sounds on the right, hyper-resonance on percussion and the trachea is deviated to the left. RR 28, O2 saturation 90%, HR 110, BP 110/90, Temp 36.5°C. How would you immediately manage this patient?
questions.solution:
• This is a primary spontaneous tension pneumothorax in a teenager. It is an emergency and can lead to cardiac arrest.
  • It needs immediate management of a large bore cannula inserted in the 2nd ICS mid-clavicular line, followed by the insertion of a chest drain in the right axilla (5th Intercostal space, mid axillary line), then with high flow oxygen 15L via a non-rebreathe mask, which will then be titrated.
  • Getting an X-ray to prove your diagnosis is not appropriate as your patient will deteriorate rapidly.

questions.text: You are asked to see a 2-year-old child who has a 12-hour history of severe diarrhoea and vomiting. He is pale and lethargic with a HR 180/min, BP 80 mmHg systolic, and capillary refill time of 7 seconds. What type of shock are they likely to be in?
questions.solution:
• This child is likely to be dehydrated from losing fluid through vomiting and diarrhoea, and may not have adequate oral intake to replace losses.
  • This has resulted in severe dehydration, evident from the increased HR (due to compensation for a low blood volume in attempt to increase BP), increased cap refill time and low BP (indicating uncompensated shock), and pale and clammy appearance.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Hypovolemic shock occurs due to a significant reduction in intravascular volume, leading to inadequate tissue perfusion and oxygen delivery. This can result in cellular hypoxia, metabolic acidosis, and multi-organ dysfunction if untreated.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical feature is less likely in a condition of hypernatremia dehydration?
questions.solution:
The following may be present in hypernatremia dehydration, whereby proportionally more water than sodium is lost from the body:

  • Jittery movements
  • Increased muscle tone
  • Hyperreflexia
  • Convulsions
  • Drowsiness or coma.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Hypernatremic dehydration occurs when there is a greater water loss relative to sodium loss, resulting in an increased plasma sodium concentration (serum sodium >145 mEq/L). It is most commonly observed in settings of inadequate water intake, excessive water loss, or high solute intake.

questions.text: After encouraging coughing, what is the next step in the management of a choking infant?
questions.solution:
CHOKING IN INFANTS:

  • In this age group a combination of back blows and chest thrusts is the recommended practice. To begin with five back blows are performed, checking after each one to see if the foreign body has been expelled.
  • Place infant on forearm- face down with head pointing towards the ground. With the hand of the rescuer supporting the jaw (keeping it open). With the free hand five back blows are given.
  • If this does not improve the situation the infant is turned over(still head down) and placed along the rescuer's arm. Then 5 chest thrusts are performed. Two fingers are placed at the lower edge of the sternum (below nipple line). If the infant is too large then they can be placed on the lap of the rescuer.

CHOKING IN CHILDREN:

  • If the child is coughing this should be encouraged. Back blows are the first step with the child supported in a leaning forward position. This should be attempted as 5 back blows with hand placement between shoulder blades, checking after each blow to see if the foreign body has been expelled.
  • If this fails the Heimlich manoeuvre should be performed. This is repeated 5 times unless the object is expelled.
  • Place the child on a flat surface (supine). Assess airway for evidence of visible object causing obstruction. Open the airway and given 5 inflation breaths. Then continue the BLS algorithm as per the Basic Life Support
  • Each time breaths are attempted look in the mouth for evidence of foreign body and remove it if visible. If effective breathing commences, place in the recovery position and monitor.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents following a head injury while running around at nursery and fell over in the playground 3 hours ago. The fall itself was unwitnessed, but the teacher stated that she saw him performing jerking movements on the ground immediately after. He is brought to you while he had vomited twice on the way. He had not vomited at school. On examination, there is no focal neurological deficit, he obeys motor commands, eyes open spontaneously but is confused. He has a laceration measuring 7cm above his Right eye. He has is known case of epilepsy. Which of the following is an indication for a CT head in this case?
questions.solution:
A GCS of <15 2 hours after the injury, or a GCS of <14 on initial assessment are both indications for a CT head.

  1. Clinical Symptoms:
    • Loss of consciousness (LOC) or altered mental status (e.g., Glasgow Coma Scale ≤15).
    • Persistent headache or vomiting (>2 episodes).
    • Post-traumatic seizures.
    • Amnesia regarding the event.
    • Signs of raised intracranial pressure (e.g., papilledema, unequal pupils).
  2. Physical Examination Findings:
    • Focal neurological deficits (e.g., hemiparesis, cranial nerve palsies).
    • Suspected skull fracture:
      • Open or depressed skull fracture.
      • Battle sign or raccoon eyes (suggestive of basal skull fracture).
    • Scalp hematoma or penetrating head injury (especially in children <2 years).

Option A: He has a diagnosis of epilepsy so is not an automatic indication for CT on its own.

Option B: Vomiting is an indication for further observation, but not an indication for CT head on its own.

It is also worth noting that in adults only 1 episode of unexplained vomiting is required for a CT head, due to vomiting being a common response to pain and trauma in children.

Option C: An unwitnessed fall is common in children, and is not an indication on its own.

KEY TAKEAWAYS: Early imaging ensures prompt diagnosis of life-threatening conditions like intracranial hemorrhage, cerebral edema, or herniation. Avoid unnecessary CT to reduce radiation exposure, particularly in paediatric patients.

questions.text: According to PALS guidelines - what is the most appropriate treatment for a 7-year-old boy, presenting with a wide QRS complex tachycardia of over 200bpm, with a capillary refill time of 4 seconds and palpable carotid pulse?
Which of the following is the most common cause of shock in paediatric patient?
questions.solution:
• Dehydration (hypovolemic) shock is the most common type of shock in paediatric population.

Common Causes in Paediatrics

  • Gastrointestinal Losses:
    • Diarrhea (e.g., rotavirus, cholera).
    • Vomiting.
  • Hemorrhage:
    • Trauma (e.g., accidents).
    • Post-surgical bleeding.
  • Burns:
    • Fluid loss through damaged skin.
  • Other Causes:
    • Inadequate fluid intake (e.g., neglect, illness).
    • Third-spacing (e.g., sepsis, nephrotic syndrome).
    • Septic shock is most common in neonates.
